In this work, lanthanum molybdenum-based perovskites “LaMoO3” with different morphologies (nanofibers, nanorods, nanospheres, and nanocubes) were synthesized and evaluated for the oxidative coupling of methane using N2O as an oxidant. The results obtained show that La2Mo3O12 is the most stable phase for the nanocubes and La2Mo2O9 for the other nanostructures. Nanofibers exhibited the best performance, followed by nanorods, nanospheres, and nanocubes. The morphology of the catalysts significantly influences the reaction by shaping its surface properties and catalytic behavior. It was also found that the reducibility and the type of reducible oxygen on the catalyst’s surface (ratio of surface to bulk oxygen) depend on morphology and primarily influence activity and selectivity. These properties are also affected by other factors as well, such as the catalyst’s basicity, which also correlates with morphology. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Perovskites Morphology effect Lanthanum OCM, N2O Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction One of the most promising processes for the synthesis of chemicals and fuels is the oxidative coupling of methane, namely, to produce ethane and ethylene [1]. It is an exothermic process that requires high temperatures to break the CH bonds of methane (Eq. (1) and 2), which unfortunately favors undesirable combustion reactions, leading to the formation of COx products (CO and CO2). (1) 2CH4 + N2O → C2H6 +H2O +N2 ΔHo 298 = −259 kJ/mol (2) 2CH4 + 2N2O → C2H4 +2H2O +N2 ΔHo 298 = −446 kJ/mol Conventional OCM catalysts are usually metal oxides and among them Na2WO4/Mn/SiO2 and Li/MgO are the most studied due to their high activity and high selectivity towards C2 hydrocarbons at high temperatures (> 700 °C) [2–6]. However, some studies with rare earth metal oxides have shown that they are active and selective at lower temperatures, namely La2O3 based catalysts with high C2 yields [7,8]. Jiang et al. [9] studied the performance of La2O3 catalysts with different morphologies and has found that C2 yields decrease, following the order: nanosheet > nanorod = nanoflowers > nanosphere. It was found that the exposed facets and the ratio of surface adsorbed oxygen to lattice oxygen, in addition to surface basicity, were responsible for catalytic performance. Huang et al. [10] showed that La2O3 nanorods have superior activity and selectivity compared to nanospheres at low temperatures due to the higher surface area, higher amounts of electron deficient oxygen species, and stronger basic surface sites. Hou et al. [11] found that rod-like La2O2CO3 have higher performance compared to the plate-like catalysts at lower temperatures (<500 °C), which was attributed to the differences in the exposed facets. Özdemir et al. [12] investigated the performance of La2O3 and La2O2CO3 with different morphologies (nanoparticle, nanorod, flower-like, nanosphere and nanofiber) at low catalytic bed reaction temperatures. They concluded that the OCM activity and selectivity of the catalysts mainly depend on the type of surface oxygen, the surface area and basicity and that La2O3 catalysts were more active and selective than La2O2CO3 catalysts. They have also confirmed that the catalyst morphology has a strong impact on the reaction performance: the best results were obtained using La2O3 with nanorod and nanofiber morphology, the highest C2 yield of 11.7 % obtained over nanofiber structure at 450 °C. In recent years, ternary oxides, namely perovskites, with the formula ABO3 containing lanthanides and/or alkaline earths (A=La, Pr, Nd, Sm, Gd, Ca, Sr, and Ba, B=Al, Ga, In, and Zr), have emerged as a new class of active OCM catalysts [1,13–17]. Their physical and chemical properties, as well as their high thermal and structural stability, high oxygen mobility, and low vacancy formation energy contribute significantly to the good C2 hydrocarbon yields obtained at low temperatures (< 700 °C) [13,18]. The incorporation of lanthanide and/or alkaline earth metals into perovskites can create electronic defects [19,20] and structural changes [21] that increase the mobility and activity of oxygen in the perovskite structure, promoting methane and oxygen activation at low temperatures and improving their OCM activity and selectivity toward light hydrocarbons [14,22]. On the other hand, molybdenum is the basis of many heterogeneous catalysts that are effective in controlling the rate and selectivity of a wide range of chemical reactions [23–28]. Nevertheless, molybdenum has been mainly used for the non-oxidative coupling of methane [29–32], as additives for OCM [33,34] and more rarely as OCM catalysts [35]. Another aspect to be taken into consideration is the type of oxidant. Molecular oxygen is the most studied oxidant but it can increase the reaction temperatures and the formation of oxidation products [36]. One strategy to improve OCM selectivity toward C2 hydrocarbons is to control the nature of the oxygen species formed using different types of oxidants [37]. The use of “softer oxidants” such as nitrous oxide (N2O) and carbon dioxide (CO2) are among the most studied alternatives [38–40]. The use of “softer oxidants” allow the formation of more selective oxygen surface species, nucleophilic species (O- and O2 -), which are important for the formation of C2 hydrocarbons [36,37,41]. A study of possible alternative oxidants and the results obtained were compiled in a recent review [36]. Although the use of CO2 as an oxidant has been the focus of recent years, the use of N2O deserves more attention due to the encouraging results obtained to date. Preparation methods can have also a tremendous influence on catalyst behavior, and OCM is no exception [13,42,43]. OCM catalysts have been synthesized by several methods, including solvothermal and hydrothermal based methods, citrate-based methods, co-precipitation techniques, and more recently electrospinning technique; offering different ways to optimize catalyst morphology, surface area, and active site distribution, which are critical to improve catalytic performance [42,44–47]. K. Jareonpanon et al. [44] prepared Na2WO4−MnxOy supported on SiO2 by electrospinning and the results showed that the catalysts prepared by electrospinning increased the CH4 conversion and C2 selectivity (C2 selectivity ≈ 60 % and CH4 conversion ≈ 35 % at 700 °C) due to the improved heat and mass transfer properties of the nanofiber catalyst compared to the powder catalyst (C2 selectivity ≈ 50 % and CH4 conversion ≈ 30 % at 700 °C). Among the various preparation techniques, electrospinning seems to stand out but, the use of electrospinning for the preparation of OCM catalysts is relatively scarce. Therefore, considering all these facts, the primary objectives of this work were the synthesis of lanthanum molybdenum-based perovskites with different morphologies (nanospheres, nanorods, nanocubes and nanofibers) and the study of their OCM performances using N2O as oxidant, which to the best of our knowledge, has never been reported in the literature. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation Nanostructured ternary oxides of the type “LaMoO3” with different morphologies were prepared by the epoxide addition method (nanospheres), the solvothermal method (nanocubes, nanorods) and the electrospinning technique (nanofibers). All chemicals used are of ACS grade or higher purity. The epoxide addition method was used to prepare the nanospheres. The process starts with the dissolution of the metal chloride precursors (purchased from Aldrich and Alpha Aesar; purity > 99.9 %) in absolute ethanol (purchased from Fischer Chemical, > 99.9 %) at room temperature. Propylene oxide (PO, Acros Organics, 99.5 %) was then added to this solution at a molar ratio between the metal chlorides and PO of 1:9 and the solution stirred. The solution was then allowed to stand at room temperature until complete gel formation. The gel was then aged in absolute ethanol at 50 °C for 48 h in a sealed vessel and dried by the organic solvent sublimation drying method, which involves exchanging solutions of 50, 80 and 100 % acetonitrile/ethanol (v/v), periods of 24 h for each concentration at 50 °C [48]. Finally, to obtain the perovskite phase, the aerogel was calcined at 800 °C for 2 h at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The product was then ground to a particle size of 200 mesh and stored. The solvothermal method is a well-established method for the synthesis of metal oxide nanostructures. It allows precise control of the size, morphology, structure, and uniformity of the product by regulating several experimental parameters such as pH, temperature, and type of solvent. In this work, it has been used to obtain nanocubes [49] and nanorods [50] of shaped lanthanum molybdenum-based perovskites. For example, nanocubes were synthesized by this method [49] by dissolving 1.5 mmol of La(CH3COO)2·5H2O and 1.5 mmol of MoCl5 in 20 mL of ethylene glycol. Then, 3.6980 g of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, MW 40,000, wt. % PVP/metals = 4, Alfa Aesar) was added, and the mixture was stirred until the complete dissolution of the starting materials. NaOH pellets were then added until the solution reached the desired pH of 12. The solution was then transferred to a Teflon cup, placed in a stainless-steel vessel autoclave and heated to 180 °C for 24 h in a temperature-controlled electric oven. After the solvothermal treatment, the solution was washed several times with deionized water and ethanol (96 % purity) and dried at 60 °C for 24 h. The final product was calcined at 800 °C for 2 h at a heating rate of 1 °C/min and then stored. The synthesis of nanorods shaped perovskites was also achieved using 1.5 mmol of La(CH3COO)2·5H2O and 1.5 mmol of MoCl5 dissolved in 20 mL of ethylenediamine followed by the addition of oxalic acid (1.5128 mg; oxalic acid/metals =4) to favor the formation of nanorods [50]. The solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated to 180 °C for 24 h in a temperature-controlled electric oven. The resulting product was then centrifuged, followed by several washes with deionized water and ethanol. It was then dried at 60 °C for 24 h in a temperature-controlled electric oven. The final product was calcined at 800 °C for 2 h at a heating rate of 1 °C/min and then stored. In the electrospinning technique [51,52], a metal precursor solution consisting of a polymer and the desired metal salts is prepared, subjected to a high voltage, and collected on a suitable target. Lanthanum - molybdenum perovskite nanofibers were prepared using this technique. As an example, the process starts with the dissolution of 42 wt. % of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, Alfa Aesar, M.W. 40,000) in 25 mL of absolute ethanol (Fischer Chemical, > 99.9 %) and then 4 mmol of the metal nitrate precursors (purity > 99.9 %, obtained from either Aldrich or Alpha Aesar) were added and dissolved in the above-mentioned solution with a La:Mo ratio of 1. The electrospinning conditions included a distance of 10 cm, an applied voltage of 15–17 kV, and a flow rate of 1 mL/h. The electrospun material thus obtained was then subjected to calcination treatment at 800 °C for 30 min at a heating rate of 1 °C/min. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Scanning Electron Microscopy and Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (SEM-EDS) were used to evaluate the morphological structure, as well as the particle size of a given sample. EDS allows also a semi-quantification of the catalysts’ surface chemical composition. SEM images were acquired using a benchtop SEM Phenom ProX G6 with CsB6 filament, operating at 15 keV and 74 µA. EDS analyses were performed with a B-U Bruker Quantax 400 EDS-SDD system. X-Ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed by a non-monochromatic double anode (Mg/Al) spectrometer from KRATOS, model XSAM800. The radiation selected to analyze the samples was the Al Kα X-radiation with energy hν = 1486.6 eV, produced with a filament current of 10 mA and a high voltage of 12 kV. The spectrometer operated in Fixed Analyzer Transmission (FAT) mode with a pass energy of 20 eV and a step of 0.1 eV. Powder samples were fixed on the XPS holder with a double-face tape and introduced in the spectrometer under a N2 flux. The sample was transferred to the analysis chamber under a secondary vacuum (∼10–7 mbar). Samples were analyzed in ultra-high vacuum, (∼10–9 mbar), at a Take-Off angle of 45° The charge shift was corrected using as reference the Binding Energy (BE) of sp3 carbon atoms bonded to other carbon atoms and/or hydrogen atoms, centered at 285 eV. 7 The quantification factors (or sensitivity factors) were those of the software Vision library: 0.278 for C 1 s, 0.780 for O 1 s, 8.143 for La 3d5/2, 3.321 for Mo 3d and 1.685 for Na 1 s. Powder X-ray diffraction technique (XRD) was used for phase identification and to assess changes after reaction and after the reducibility studies by temperature programmed reduction under hydrogen (H2-TPR). Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were collected on a D2Phaser Bruker diffractometer (Cu, kα monochromatic radiation, λ=1.5406 Å). The operational settings for all scans were voltage=30 kV; current= 10 mA; 2θ scan range 20–80° using a step size of 0.03° at time per step 3.5 s. We calculated the lattice parameters and unit cell volume of all perovskites, including the La₂Mo₃O₁₂ phase, using the UnitCell software. The program requires the input of the main diffraction peak positions (2θ) and the corresponding Miller indices (hkl). Based on this input, the software computes the lattice parameters and unit cell volumes. For the cubic La2Mo2O9 phase, the lattice parameter (a) was calculated using the formula for cubic systems: d × h 2 + k 2 + l 2 , where d is the interplanar spacing obtained from Bragg’s law, d = λ 2 s i n θ . In this expression, λ is the X-ray wavelength and h, k, and l are the Miller indices of the analyzed diffraction peak. The crystallite sizes were estimated using the Scherrer equation: d i = k × λ β × cos θ . Here, di is the average size of the crystallite; k is a dimensionless shape factor with a the typical value of which is about 0.9, though it varies from 0.8 to 1.39 depending on the crystallite's actual shape; λ is the X-ray wavelength; β is the width at half height of the diffraction peak; and θ is the Bragg angle. Specific surface areas were determined by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller method (BET). The measurements were carried out using a Micrometrics ChemiSorb 2720 – ChemiSoft TPx system. The samples were analyzed under a flux of 20 mL/min, mixture of 30 % N2 in helium (P/P0=0.3). For each sample, three replicate measurements were carried out and three cycles of N2 adsorption and desorption recorded. The process involves the adsorption and formation of a monolayer of N2 at the temperature of liquid nitrogen, followed by N2 desorption after removing the liquid nitrogen and natural warming to room temperature. The BET surface areas were calculated from the desorption peaks using the Micromeritics software installed, through a calibration curve (y = 0.4367x+0.0004, where x is the peak area and y is the adsorbed N2vol) previously prepared using the addition of known N2vol and recording of the detector’s response, which allows, from the areas measured for the desorption peaks, to calculate the volume of N2 adsorbed. The reducibility of the nanostructured perovskites was studied by temperature programmed reduction under hydrogen (H2-TPR), performed on a Micrometrics equipment (ChemiSorb 2720 – ChemiSoft TPx system). The samples were placed in a specific Micromeritics quartz type U reactor and reduced under a 10 % H2 in argon mixture, total flow of 20 mL/min, at a heating rate of 10 °C/min from room temperature to 1050 °C. Optimized resolution was obtained by careful choice of the sample weight (10–20 mg). Considering the reactions that may occur, the different types of reducible species present in the catalysts can be identified and the maximum reduction temperature rates (Tm) for each one determined. Quantitative total and partial H2 uptakes were evaluated by integration of the H2-TPR peaks employing a calibration curve obtained from H2-TPR studies using the reduction of NiO powder (Aldrich, 99.999 % purity) as reference (NiO + H2 → Ni +H2O): H2 uptake (mol)=4.93 × 10–6 x peak area. The acid-base properties of the nanostructured perovskites were evaluated by studying their behavior on the dehydrogenation/dehydration of 2-propanol (isopropanol) used as model reaction [53–56]. The catalysts were placed in fixed-bed U-shaped Pyrex reactor at atmospheric pressure and in a temperature range of 175 to 250 °C, under a continuous flow of a mixture of 0.5 % (v/v) of isopropanol in air N2/O2:80/20 v/v) with a GHSV of 1012 mL/gcatalyst.h. The reactor outlet gas composition was analysed online by gas chromatography using an Agilent 7280D chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and an HP_PLOT_U capillary column (L = 25 m, ID = 0.32 mm). Two competitive reactions can occur, the dehydrogenation of 2-propanol leading to the production of acetone and hydrogen, and the dehydration of 2-propanol, where propene, water, and small amounts of diisopropyl ether are produced. The yields of acetone (YA) and propene (YP) are used to infer the acid–base character of the nanostructures. 2.3 Catalytic tests Catalytic studies were carried out at atmospheric pressure in a fixed-bed U-shaped quartz reactor, plug-flow type reactor, with a quartz frit and an internal volume of 7 cm3. Mass flow controllers (Aalborg series A) were used to control CH4, He (carrier gas) and oxidant (e.g. N2O) flows; all gases supplied by Air Liquide, purity Alphagaz2. The reactor was placed in a tubular oven and the reaction temperature controlled by a thermocouple placed near the catalytic bed. Unless otherwise stated, a gaseous mixture of CH4/N2O molar ratio of 1 [N2O (10 %), CH4 (10 %) and He (80 %)] was used and the reaction studied with an adequate gas hourly space velocity (GHSV, mL of CH4 / g of catalyst / h) of 15,000, m = 10–20 mg. These experimental parameters were optimized to ensure a reaction free of diffusional problems (either mass or heat) using a proper GHSV. The outlet gas was cooled in an ice-water trap and its composition analyzed on-line by gas chromatography using a Restek ShinCarbon ST column (L = 2.0 m, ϕ = 1/8 in., ID = 1 mm, 100/200 mesh) and an Agilent 4890D GC equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a 6-port gas sampling valve with a 250 μL loop. The outlet gas is also cooled in an ice-water trap, before the analysis, to avoid column contamination, namely by water. The main products detected were C2H6 and C2H4 (combined selectivity > 70 %) and CO. Catalyst activity was defined as the number of mL of methane converted per g of catalyst and per hour (mLCH4/g.h). Quantification of reagents and products was confirmed by an external standard method using certified mixtures of CH4, N2O, CO2, CO, C2H6 and C2H4 (Air Liquide) as reference. The confidence level was better than 95 %. The catalytic activity for each sample (methane yield and the selectivity for each product) was calculated as follows: CH4 conversion ( %) = ([CH4]i - [CH4]f/ [CH4] i × 100; CxHy selectivity ( %) = [CxHy]f/ ([CH4]i - [CH4]f) × 100; CO selectivity ( %) = [CO]f/ ([CH4]i - [CH4]f) × 100; CO2 selectivity ( %) = [CO2]f / ([CH4]i - [CH4]f) × 100; CxHy yield ( %) = (CH4 conversion × CxHy selectivity)/ 100, where [ C H 4 ] i is the initial concentration of methane and [ x ] f is the final concentration of reagents and products. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of lanthanum-molybdenum perovskites synthesized in different morphologies and crystallographic phases. The most common and stable phase, La2Mo2O9 [57–59], with a cubic structure, was observed for the nanospheres, nanorods and nanofibers morphologies, which implies that during the synthesis Mo (V) is oxidized to Mo(VI). A different phase was obtained for the nanocube morphology, La2Mo3O12, with a monoclinic structure and again the oxidation of Mo (V) to Mo(VI) [60,61].This difference in phase formation can be attributed to the synthesis conditions of the nanocubes, which can influence the arrangement and crystallization of atoms during the synthesis process. Furthermore, the formation of other lanthanum or molybdenum phases, such as La2O3, La(OH)3 or MoO3 was not observed, and the perovskites were successfully prepared with a high degree of purity. As presented in Table 1 , the catalysts crystallite average sizes, and the lattice parameters determined through XRD refinement exhibit significant variations. Crystallite sizes range from 14 to 30 nm, with a clear distinction observed among all the perovskite nanostructures, following the trend: nanofibers < nanocubes < nanospheres < nanorods. Crystalline size can directly influence the number of catalytically active sites since larger crystallite sizes reduce the number of active sites due to fewer grain boundaries, whereas smaller crystallite sizes expose more reactive sites, which may improve their catalytic activity. Lattice parameters analysis revealed that nanocubes exhibited a more complex crystalline structure, monoclinic crystalline structure, displaying a larger unit cell volume, with a larger interatomic spacing that can facilitate the diffusion of the reagents and products molecules within the catalyst. The remaining nanostructures have a cubic crystalline structure, exhibited smaller unit cell volumes, a denser structure and a crystalline size that increases following the order: nanofibers < nanospheres < nanorods. These differences in structural properties can significantly impact their catalytic behavior. Table 2 shows the BET surface areas of the nanostructured perovskites. All measured surface areas are below 10 m2/gcat. Contrary to the anticipated correlation between nanofiber morphology and surface area, the highest surface was not observed in the nanofibers; instead, it was measured over the nanocubes. These low surface areas values are attributed to the high temperatures and extended calcination times required for the synthesis of pure-phase perovskites, a process known to result in low surface areas [62]. The surface morphology of the nanostructured perovskites was analyzed by SEM before and after the calcination treatment (Fig. 2 and 3 ). The objectives of this analysis were double: firstly, to confirm that the calcination step was successful in achieving well-defined nanostructures, and secondly, to obtain insights into the initial particle shapes, size, and sintering distribution, as well as structural evolution during the heat treatment process. Comparing the SEM images obtained before and after the calcination treatment reveals that some melting occurred for the nanospheres, nanorods and nanocubes. This phenomenon is likely attributable to the melting temperature of molybdenum oxide (m.p. of MoO3 = 795 °C). In contrast, the melting is less pronounced for the nanofibers given the short calcination time of 30 min. A calcination time of 2 h was used for the other nanostructures because a shorter time of 30 min to 1 h 30 min is not enough for the formation of La-Mo perovskite phase due to the greater crystallization complexity of these nanostructures. One example of this complexity is the evolution of the nanorods from a nanoflower of nanorods to well-separated nanorods after calcination. Furthermore, an XRD analysis was performed after the OCM reaction (Fig. 4 ). The results confirmed that the crystalline phases were the same before and after reaction. This indicates the structural stability of the catalysts, without a significant variation in crystallite sizes. Figs. 5 and S1 shows the H2-TPR profile obtained for the lanthanum-molybdenum perovskite nanostructures, the second with deconvoluted peaks. These profiles show at least two main groups of peaks, with maximum reduction temperatures that are dependent on the perovskite morphology. The nanofibers exhibit the lowest reduction temperatures (725 °C), with nanorods (783 °C), nanocubes (817 °C) and nanospheres (836 °C) following in sequence. These high-temperature peaks of La2Mo2O9 or La2Mo3O12 correspond to the reduction of bulk oxygens (O2 and O2 2 ) and the formation of other perovskites (Eqs. (3) and 4). On the other hand, peaks at lower temperatures can be observed in the ≈ 500–650 °C temperature range and were attributed to surface oxygens reduction, which is more evident for nanofibers and assigned to catalyst surface reduction or reduction of surface O and O2 species responsible for the formation of C2 hydrocarbons products [9]. Furthermore, XRD analysis was performed after H2-TPR (Fig. 6 ) shows only the patterns of metallic Mo and La2MoO6. From the literature, it is known that at 700 °C La2Mo2O9 is directly reduced into the amorphous phase La2Mo2O7-y, whereas at 760 °C reduction occurs through an intermediate crystallized La7Mo7O30 (≅ La2Mo2O8.57) phase before amorphization [63]. Therefore, taking that into account, reduction reactions occur during H2-TPR as depicted in Eqs. (3) and 4. The first for nanospheres, nanorods and nanofibers and the second for nanocubes. (3) 2La2Mo2O9 + 3.43H2 → La2Mo2O8.57 + La2MoO6 + Mo + 3·43H2O (4) La2Mo3O12 + 3.69H2 → 0.9La2Mo2O8. 57 + 0.1La2MoO6 + 1.1Mo + 3·69H2O Quantitatively, the ratio between H2 real consumed and H2 expected to be consumed was found to be equal to 1.1, 0.9, 1.0, 1.2 ± 0.1 for nanospheres, nanorods, nanocubes and nanofibers, respectively (Table 3 ). Table 4 presents the conversion and products selectivity of nanostructured lanthanum-molybdenum perovskites and reference oxides (La2O3 and MoO3) for the dehydrogenation/dehydration of 2-propanol used as a model reaction. The yields of acetone (YA) and propene (YP) are used to infer the acid–base character of the nanostructures. Lanthanide molybdates typically exhibit a moderate to strong Lewis’s acidity, primarily due to the presence of Mo⁶⁺ centers capable of accepting electron pairs. Additionally, the La-O framework contributes weak to moderate basicity, particularly through surface oxygen anions that can donate electron density. The results obtained confirm that nanostructured lanthanum-molybdenum perovskites exhibit an enhanced but predominantly basic character. Among the various nanostructures, nanofibers demonstrated the highest yield in acetone (339), followed by nanorods, nanospheres and nanocubes (216,159 and 153, respectively), indicating a decreasing density of basic sites. This suggests that the morphology of the catalyst strongly influences its acid–base properties and, consequently, its catalytic behavior. X-ray Photoelectron spectroscopy was employed to analyze the surface composition and chemical states of the elements present in the samples. The spectra were subsequently acquired for the regions of interest, specifically focusing on La 3d (around 840 eV), Mo 3d (around 235 eV), O 1 s (around 530 eV), and C 1 s (around 285 eV) for all the perovskite nanostructures. Fig. 7 shows the peaks corresponding to La 3d5/2 region. All three perovskite nanostructures exhibit identical La 3d5/2 regions, each fitted with four peaks. The La 3d5/2 region comprises two main peaks, 4.3 ± 0.2 eV apart, which arise from a multiplet state splitting due to the 3d core hole and valence electrons coupling [64]. The most intense peak, consistently centered at 835.1 ± 0.2 eV in all samples, is attributed to La3+ species, as reported in the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) XPS database [65]. The peak that fits around 839 eV corresponds to the multiplet structure. We acknowledge that deconvoluting La 3d spectra is challenging due to the strong multiplet splitting of La₂O₃. During the analysis, we only observed signals consistent with La₂O₃. Additional peaks indicating significant contributions from La(OH)₃ or La₂(CO₃)₃ were not observed in this range. This conclusion is supported by XRD analysis, which confirmed the absence of secondary phases, such as carbonates or hydroxides. This aligns with the high-temperature calcination conditions used in the synthesis process. Fig. 8 shows the peaks corresponding to Mo 3d region. All three nanostructures exhibit identical Mo 3d regions that were each fitted with four peaks, corresponding to two doublet peaks. In Fig. 8, a spin-orbit splitting (with components 3d5/2, 3d3/2) is shown. The different doublets are attributed to different oxidation states of molybdenum. The most intense peaks of the doublet (Mo 3d5/2) are centered at 232.9 ± 0.1 eV and 236.1 ± 0.1 eV, and attributed to Mo6+. The residual presence of Mo5+ (doublets centered at 230.9 and 234.10.1 eV) is consistent with previously reported signatures of Mo5+ in similar molybdenum-based oxide catalysts. This assignment aligns with data from the NIST database and with previously reported data on MoO3 catalysts [66]. This finding aligns with expectations, as in the lanthanum-molybdenum perovskite phase (La2Mo2O9 or La2Mo3O12), molybdenum predominantly exists in the Mo6+ oxidation state. The presence of Mo5+ is likely due to partial reduction, or even due to the creation of oxygen vacancies or defects in the lattice structure during synthesis or calcination treatment, resulting in a residual mixture of oxidation states. Fig. 9 shows the peaks corresponding to the O 1 s regions. The three nanostructures exhibit similar regions, yet there were differences in the O 1 s regions. Specifically, the nanospheres and the nanofibers displayed two distinct peaks, while only one peak was observed for the nanocubes. It is evident that all nanostructures exhibit a peak centered at 530.2 ± 0.1 eV (for the nanocubes) and 530.6 ± 0.1 eV (nanospheres and nanofibers), attributed to lattice oxygen atoms from MoO3, and La2O3. For the three nanostructures a qualitative and quantitative analysis was conducted to determine the evolution of the Biding Energies (BE, eV) and the amount of surface elements in each sample. Table 5 shows the BE for La 3d, Mo 3d and O 1 s fitted peaks for all the nanostructures. In all cases, the BE assigned to La3+ 3d5/2, Mo6+ 3d5/2 and O1s (O-metal) decreases and follows the order: nanospheres < nanofibers < nanocubes, indicating that the nucleophilicity of the oxygens (ability to donate electrons, Lewis bases) decreases from the nanospheres to the nanocubes. Table 6 shows the overall atomic concentrations of all the elements for all the nanostructures obtained by XPS. The differences in atomic concentrations suggest that morphology plays an important role in influencing both the distribution and concentration of the elements. The atomic concentration of O1s is higher for the nanofibers, which are the nanostructures with more nucleophilic oxygens. Therefore, the possibility of oxygen vacancy formation, which is so important in catalysis, is more important on the nanofibers. Nanofibers also have greater O/metals ratios and the high possibility of oxygen vacancies in this morphology facilitates redox activity and electron transfer processes. These processes are essential for catalytic reactions such as the oxidative coupling of methane reaction and allow us to expect superior catalytic activity when compared to the other nanostructures. 3.2 Catalytic behavior The OCM reaction was studied using N2O as an oxidant. The nanostructured lanthanum-molybdenum perovskite with nanofiber morphology produced the best results either in terms of both methane conversion and C2H4 yield, followed by the nanorods, nanosphere and nanocube morphologies (Figs. 10 and 11 ). Applying the Arrhenius equation to the evolution of the activity with respect to the temperature allow us to determine the apparent activation energies (Ea). The order of these energies clearly depends on morphology: 209, 190, 234, and 240 kJ/mol for the nanofibers, nanorods, nanospheres and nanocubes, respectively (Figure S2). Except for the nanorods, this sequence explains the observed decline in activity according to morphology. Catalytic behavior is predominantly influenced by factors such as the acid-base properties, the oxygen lability and the ratio of surface-adsorbed oxygen to lattice oxygen of the catalysts. The findings presented in Figs. 12 and S5 (basicity), Table 3 and Figures S3 and S4 (reducibility), and Fig. 13 (ratio of surface-adsorbed oxygen to lattice oxygen) support this assertion. These Figures demonstrate the following: i) An increase in basicity (acetone yield) enhances C2 yield (Fig. 12); ii) Methane conversion depends strongly on the reducibility of the catalysts (Figure S3 and Table 3), with the highest methane conversion occurring with the highest reducibility (lowest Tm) of the fibers; iii) Reducibility exhibits an inverse relationship with C2 selectivity (Figure S4); iv) Methane conversion and C2 yield correlate well with the ratio of surface adsorbed oxygen (Osurf) to lattice oxygen (Obulk), as calculated from the TPR data (Fig. 13 and Table 3). Surface-adsorbed oxygen species (O- and O2 -) are widely considered to be efficient at enhancing C2 hydrocarbon selectivity. Conversely, lattice oxygens (O2- and O2 2-) are responsible for CO and CO2 production by complete oxidation. These findings explain the high C2 hydrocarbon yields over the nanofibers and the lower yields obtained with the other morphologies. This behavior is consistent with the results reported by other authors who found that the basicity of the catalysts improves C2 hydrocarbon yields [12,67,68]. This improvement is due to the increased desorption rate of electron-rich ethylene, which prevents further oxidation to COx. The results of this study also suggest that the role of bonded surface lattice oxygens and their reducibility / strength is crucial. Reducibility correlates well with the rate of methane conversion; the higher the ratio of surface adsorbed oxygen to lattice oxygen, as determined by TPR, the higher the activity and the C2 yield. The behavior of the nanocubes, which have the lowest conversion and yield in C2 hydrocarbons, is only slightly inferior to those of the nanspheres. Additionally, the ratio of surface to bulk oxygen species is much lower than expected. This seems to indicate that the generation of O2- and O2 2- (e.g. via O2 → O2 - → O- → O2-) and the formation of COx products [69] are enhanced beyond what expected by such morphology. These findings appear to substantiate the hypothesis that catalytic activity and selectivity are influenced by various factors, such as basicity, reducibility (oxygen lability), and the ratio of surface to bulk oxygen, which depends on nanostructure morphology. 4 Conclusions Lanthanum molybdenum-based perovskites with different morphologies (nanospheres, nanorods, nanocubes and nanofibers) were successfully synthesized and tested for the oxidative coupling of methane using N2O as oxidant. The dominant phases observed were La2Mo3O12 for the nanocubes and La2Mo2O9 for the other morphologies. Catalytic performance was strongly morphology-dependent, with the optimal outcomes observed for nanofibers, followed by nanocubes, nanospheres, and nanorods. The reaction starts at 650 °C for all morphologies, and the highest rate of methane conversion and the yields of C2 hydrocarbons were attained over the nanofibers, followed by nanorods, nanospheres and nanocubes. The catalytic activity and selectivity are influenced by various factors, such as basicity, reducibility (oxygen lability), and the ratio of surface to bulk oxygens. The evolution of selectivity, i.e. the production of ethylene, is predominantly influenced by the catalyst’s basic strength, increasing with it. In contrast, catalytic activity is contingent on the lability / strength of the lattice oxygens, with higher lability/reducibility corresponding to higher activity. Therefore, it can be concluded that the morphology of the catalyst has a significant influence on their OCM performance by shaping the surface properties and the catalytic behavior. coredata.dc:description: In this work, lanthanum molybdenum-based perovskites “LaMoO3” with different morphologies (nanofibers, nanorods, nanospheres, and nanocubes) were synthesized and evaluated for the oxidative coupling of methane using N2O as an oxidant. The results obtained show that La2Mo3O12 is the most stable phase for the nanocubes and La2Mo2O9 for the other nanostructures. Nanofibers exhibited the best performance, followed by nanorods, nanospheres, and nanocubes. The morphology of the catalysts significantly influences the reaction by shaping its surface properties and catalytic behavior. It was also found that the reducibility and the type of reducible oxygen on the catalyst’s surface (ratio of surface to bulk oxygen) depend on morphology and primarily influence activity and selectivity. These properties are also affected by other factors as well, such as the catalyst’s basicity, which also correlates with morphology.
